title: Horace McCoy Noir Collection (8 Novels and Short Stories)
description:
Author of pulp stories, primarily for Black Mask, Horace McCoy is mainly remembered for his dark, tragic, and occasionally violent novels, several of which have been made into notable films. A memorable work of noir fiction and a classic film is They Shoot Horses, DonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t They? (1935), filmed in 1969 with Sydney Pollack as the director, which achieved its aim of illustrating the pain and hopelessness of the Great Depression, using a marathon dance contest as a metaphor, with the exhausting and pointless expenditure of energy for participants being analogous to the plight of the majority of Americans; No Pockets in a Shroud (1937) was filmed in France in 1975.

Novels:
I Should Have Stayed Home
No Pockets in a Shroud
They Shoot Horses, Don't They?
Kiss Tomorrow Goodbye

Short Stories:
Bombs for the General
Frost Rides Alone
Trapped by Silver
The Mopper-Up
